projects.title: Gomukhasana
projects.description: A Sanskrit word, Gomukhasana literally translates into a cow face posture (go ‚Äì cow, mukha ‚Äì face, asana ‚Äì pose). According to Gheranda Samhita, it¬†strengthens the respiratory system. If practiced for 10¬†min. or more then¬†it eradicates tiredness, fatigue,¬†stress.

projects.title: Dhanurasana
projects.description: Dhanurasana has been named after the shape the body takes while performing it ‚Äì that of a bow. Dhanu means bow and asana means posture or pose. Just as a well-strung bow is an asset to a warrior, a well-stretched body helps keep you flexible with a good posture. According to Gheranda Samhita, it improves flexibility of the body and helps in¬†removing¬†extra accumulated¬†fat¬†of abdomen.

projects.title: Paschimottanasana
projects.description: is a classic pose from Hatha yoga. It gives the whole back of your body a good stretch, from your calves to your hamstrings (back of the thighs) to your spine.

projects.title: Ardhamatsyendrasana
projects.description: Matsyendrasana, Matsyendra's Pose or Lord of the Fishes Pose, is a seated twisting asana in hatha yoga and modern yoga as exercise. The full form is the difficult Paripurna Matsyendrasana. A common and easier variant is Ardha Matsyendrasana. According to Gheranda Samhita, this posture expands the muscles of one half of the back and abdomen and compresses the muscles of the other half. It makes the spinal nerves healthy, makes the back muscles flexible.

projects.title: Kukkutasana
projects.description: Kukkut means a cockerel or rooster. Therefore Kukkutasana means Cockerel Pose or Rooster Pose. When performed, the posture looks like a cockerel. The name comes from the Sanskrit words kukku·π≠ƒÅ meaning 'cockerel' and asana (‡§Ü‡§∏‡§®) meaning 'posture' or 'seat'.
